title: Chapter 2 Review - Practice & Application
description: Review and practice everything from Chapter 2

content.instructions: Test your knowledge of numbers, nouns, use of the prefix 'ja' and introductions from lessons 6-9.

exercises.question: What is the number 'Elfu mia achiel gi mia achiel gi piero aboro gochiko'
The word 'puro' means 'to farm'. What would you call a farmer?
What is the plural of 'jalweny'?
exercises.explanation: The prefix 'ja' turns into 'jo' to make the plural form.

exercises.question: What is the plural of the word 'thuol'? ('thuol' means 'a snake')
exercises.explanation: It ends in 'l' so it's plural takes the 'nde' ending

exercises.question: The word 'gol' is a loan word from English meaning 'goal' as in a football match. How would you say '5 goals'?
What is the meaning of 'ia kanye'?
Translate 'In nyakwar Mary?'
options: You are the grandchild of Mary?
You are the daughter of Mary?

exercises.question: What do you call a citizen of Japan?
What does the verb 'telo' mean?
exercises.explanation: It means 'to lead'. A leader would be called 'Jatelo'.

exercises.question: What is the meaning of the word 'del'?
What is the plural of the word 'Rabuon'?
What do you call a black person?

content.instructions: Introduce yourself to the world in Dholuo using what you've learned. Start by sharing your name, where you come from, who your parents and grandparents are, and the work you do.
prompts: Start by sharing your name: 'An iluoongani Otieno' (My name is Otieno)
Say where you come from: 'Aa Seme' (I come from Seme)
Mention your parents and/or grandparents: 'An wuod/nyar Peter' or 'An nyakwar Auma'
Share what you do: 'An nyathi skul' (I am a student) or 'An jathieth' (I am a doctor).
content.example: An iluongani Otieno. Aa Seme. An nyar Peter to an nyakwar Auma. An nyathi skul.

content.instructions: Listen to the audio clip and answer the questions below. You can replay the audio up to 3 times.
content.transcript: An Otieno. Adhi limogi. Gin be gidhi dala. Nyathi maduong' otedo maber.
content.translation: I am Otieno. I'm going to visit them. They are also going home. The big child cooked well.

questions.question: What is the speaker's name?
questions.explanation: The speaker says 'An Otieno' meaning 'I am Otieno'

questions.question: Where is the speaker going?
questions.explanation: 'Adhi limogi' means 'I'm going to visit them'

questions.question: Who cooked well?
questions.explanation: 'Nyathi maduong' otedo maber' means 'The big child cooked well'

content.congratulations: Excellent work! You've completed Chapter 2 and are well on your way to speaking Dholuo like a native.
content.summary: In this chapter you learned: how to count, how to form the plural of some nouns, and how to introduce yourself in Luo.
content.next_steps: Ready for Chapter 3? You'll learn more about nouns, verbs, how to ask questions and how to describe your family.
